What to do for fun

Dorm Life
Academic Rigor
Tips for prospective students
In three sentences
Comments
Our campus is patrolled 24/7 not only by our public safety officers, but the Buffalo Police Department as well.
We have both a social sorority and fraternity, and numerous academic greek societies.
There is a club for EVERYONE at this school! At the student fair you'll find yourself signing up for more clubs than you could have ever dreamed of at a school.
Those who loved to be involved, and those who love to help others. Canisius is all about giving back, and service learning is a huge part of our program here.
We are the closest school to the main shopping districts and downtown Buffalo. Students are also given metro cards to take the subway for free, so you always have something to do!
Multiple dining locations, and the ability to cook for yourself!
Some of the biggest dorms you will ever see in a college. And once you're an upperclassman, you can live in on campus apartments!
Student's are held to a high standard of education, and professors are always willing to put in the extra time if you need help.
Apply for scholarships; Canisius has lots of academic rewards available!
A small school of about 3,000 students, but campus is spread out throughout the city so you get a real urban feel!
pageTitle: Canisius College Reviews: Student Reviews and Ratings | Cappex
TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {202072=© 2015, Cappex.com, LLC, 161056=Get your application in early! The earlier your application is in and you make your deposit, the more housing options you have. If you qualify for honors or are interested in service, you can live on the honors or Ignatian floors. These two floors are in the freshman hall that was built in 2008. They are modern and very spacious. Another benefit is that they are air-conditioned. Another tip is if you have taken college classes in high school, send them to the college to see if they transfer. The more core requirements you can get out of the way, the faster you can start working on the classes that really count towards your major.}
textBeforeTable: 12/31/2009 Reviewer is A current student here. 9 out of 9 people found this review useful. 1 of 42 Lauren from NY Check out reviews left by other students or leave your own review. textAfterTable: Bang for the buck Not initially showing it's worth unless you can get most of it paid for. The higher classes may prove to make all of this worth it but the starting classes are sub-par in my opinion. The only class that put out as much information as you'd expect from a higher learning class was History of Modern Europe and, though I enjoyed the class, it's not applicable to most degrees. Am enjoying being here I don't believe I am a good view on the good points of the school, as I really didn't spend time on campus in my first year more than for my classes during the school year. What time I did spend there was very enjoyable, with many things to do in the evening. There are many places around campus to hang out with friends, a lot of events that happen every week, It's hard to find a day that there is nothing you can do. Am learning a lot Yes and no. Much of the 100 classes are review if you have taken high school level versions of the classes. You can cruise through with ease if you are motivated to learn and complete course work and home work. You won't get much
